summary: This chapter emphasizes the importance of reflection and review for continuous improvement and course correction, using examples from sports, business, and personal life. It highlights Pat Riley's CBE program with the Lakers, where players improved by 1% through reflection and review, leading to NBA championships. The chapter also discusses the reflection practices of top performers like Iluud Kipchoge, Katie Ledecky, and Chris Rock, as well as executives and investors who use decision journals. The author advocates for annual reviews and integrity reports to identify mistakes, revisit core values, and set higher standards. Reflection provides perspective, helps break limiting beliefs, and allows for adjustments to habits and identity. It also cautions against clinging too tightly to one identity, suggesting redefining oneself to maintain important aspects even when roles change. The chapter concludes by emphasizing the need to periodically check if old habits and beliefs are still serving you, as a lack of self-awareness can be detrimental. The chapter uses the Sorites paradox to illustrate the power of small, repeated actions in transforming one's life, emphasizing that success is an ongoing process of refinement rather than a destination.

evidence.verbatim_text: [05:16:56,382,05:17:03,184] Similar to the British cycling team that we discussed in Chapter 1, the Lakers sought peak performance by getting slightly better each day.
[05:17:04,460,05:17:12,986] Riley was careful to point out that CBE was not merely about points or statistics, but about giving your best effort spiritually, mentally, and physically.

[05:17:13,847,05:17:28,857] Players got credit for allowing an opponent to run into you when you know that a foul will be called against him, diving for loose balls, going after rebounds whether you are likely to get them or not, helping a teammate when the player he's guarding has surged past him, and other unsung hero deeds.
[05:17:30,268,05:17:38,373] The CBE number was calculated for all of a player's games, and it was the average CBE that a player was asked to improve by 1% over the season.
[05:17:39,374,05:17:45,737] Riley compared each player's current CBE to not only their past performances, but also those of other players in the league.
[05:17:46,558,05:17:53,242] As Riley put it, we rank team members alongside league opponents who played the same position and have similar role definitions.

[05:17:54,548,05:18:05,118] Sports writer Jackie McMullen noted, Riley trumpeted the top performers in the league in bold lettering on the blackboard each week and measured them against the corresponding players on his own roster.
[05:18:06,180,05:18:11,905] Solid, reliable players generally rated a score in the 600s, while elite players scored at least 800.
[05:18:13,206,05:18:18,171] Magic Johnson, who submitted 138 triple doubles in his career, often scored over 1,000.
[05:18:19,817,05:18:25,703] The Lakers also emphasized year-over-year progress by making historical comparisons of CBE data.
[05:18:26,524,05:18:36,794] Riley said, We stacked the month of November 1986 next to November 1985 and showed the players whether they were doing better or worse than at the same point last season.
[05:18:37,534,05:18:42,900] Then we showed them how their performance figures for December 1986 stacked up against November's.
[05:18:44,188,05:18:50,653] The Lakers rolled out the CBE program in October 1986. Eight months later, they were NBA champions.
[05:18:51,393,05:18:59,279] The following year, Pat Riley led his team to another title as the Lakers became the first team in 20 years to win back-to-back NBA championships.
[05:19:00,140,05:19:04,904] Afterward, he said, sustaining an effort is the most important thing for any enterprise.
[05:19:05,444,05:19:10,668] The way to be successful is to learn how to do things right, then do them the same way every time.
[05:19:11,762,05:19:18,552] The CBE program is a prime example of the power of reflection and review. The Lakers were already talented.
[05:19:19,113,05:19:24,802] CBE helped them get the most out of what they had and made sure their habits improved rather than declined.
[05:19:25,940,05:19:34,645] Reflection and review enables the long-term improvement of all habits because it makes you aware of your mistakes and helps you consider possible paths for improvement.
[05:19:35,385,05:19:40,368] Without reflection, we can make excuses, create rationalizations, and lie to ourselves.
[05:19:40,968,05:19:45,871] We have no process for determining whether we are performing better or worse compared to yesterday.
[05:19:47,148,05:19:54,115] Top performers in all fields engage in various types of reflection and review, and the process doesn't have to be complex.
[05:19:54,936,05:20:00,982] Kenyan runner Iluud Kipchoge is one of the greatest marathon runners of all time and an Olympic gold medalist.
[05:20:01,582,05:20:08,189] He still takes notes after every practice in which he reviews his training for the day and searches for areas that can be improved.
[05:20:09,328,05:20:17,571] Similarly, gold medal swimmer Katie Ledecky records her wellness on a scale of 1 to 10 and includes notes on her nutrition and how well she slept.
[05:20:18,351,05:20:20,892] She also records the times posted by other swimmers.
[05:20:21,592,05:20:27,469] At the end of each week, her coach goes over her notes and adds his thoughts.  It's not just athletes either.
[05:20:27,869,05:20:34,736] When comedian Chris Rock is preparing fresh material, he will first appear at small nightclubs dozens of times and test hundreds of jokes.
[05:20:35,396,05:20:40,581] He brings a notepad on stage and records which bits go over well and where he needs to make adjustments.
[05:20:41,381,05:20:45,205] The few killer lines that survive will form the backbone of his new show.

[05:20:46,720,05:20:55,566] I know of executives and investors who keep a decision journal in which they record the major decisions they make each week, why they made them, and what they expect the outcome to be.
[05:20:56,327,05:21:01,350] They review their choices at the end of each month or year to see where they were correct and where they went wrong.
[05:21:02,471,05:21:06,294] If you're interested in keeping your own decision journal, I created a template for doing so.
[05:21:06,654,05:21:12,518] You can find it included as part of the habit journal available at atomichabits.com slash journal.
[05:21:14,047,05:21:17,830] Improvement is not just about learning habits, it's also about fine-tuning them.

[05:21:18,531,05:21:28,279] Reflection and review ensures that you spend your time on the right things and make course corrections whenever necessary, like Pat Riley adjusting the effort of his players on a nightly basis.
[05:21:29,080,05:21:32,162] You don't want to keep practicing a habit if it becomes ineffective.
[05:21:33,103,05:21:36,264] Personally, I employ two modes of reflection and review.
[05:21:37,144,05:21:41,465] Each December, I perform an annual review in which I reflect on the previous year.
[05:21:42,405,05:21:49,207] I tally my habits for the year by counting up how many articles I published, how many workouts I put in, how many new places I visited, and more.
[05:21:50,107,05:21:55,448] You can see my previous annual reviews at jamesclear.com slash annual dash review.
[05:21:56,532,05:22:02,923] Finally, I reflect on my progress, or lack thereof, by answering three questions. One, what went well this year?
[05:22:03,684,05:22:07,471] Two, what didn't go so well this year? Three, what did I learn?
[05:22:09,023,05:22:15,568] Six months later, when summer rolls around, I conduct an integrity report. Like everyone, I make a lot of mistakes.
[05:22:16,128,05:22:21,392] My integrity report helps me realize where I went wrong and motivates me to get back on course.
[05:22:22,072,05:22:26,956] I use it as a time to revisit my core values and consider whether I have been living in accordance with them.
[05:22:27,796,05:22:32,820] This is when I reflect on my identity and how I can work toward being the type of person I wish to become.
[05:22:33,740,05:22:38,544] You can see my previous integrity reports at jamesclear.com slash integrity.
[05:22:39,817,05:22:45,859] My yearly integrity report answers three questions. One, what are the core values that drive my life and work?
[05:22:46,599,05:22:53,100] Two, how am I living and working with integrity right now? Three, how can I set a higher standard in the future?
[05:22:54,601,05:23:00,402] These two reports, the annual review and the integrity report, don't take very long. It's just a few hours a year.
[05:23:01,062,05:23:02,903] But they are crucial periods of refinement.
[05:23:03,722,05:23:06,904] They prevent the gradual slide that happens when I don't pay close attention.
[05:23:07,644,05:23:15,028] They provide an annual reminder to revisit my desired identity and consider how my habits are helping me become the type of person I wish to be.
[05:23:15,849,05:23:22,092] They indicate when I should upgrade my habits and take on new challenges, and when I should dial my efforts back and focus on the fundamentals.
[05:23:23,253,05:23:25,555] Reflection can also bring a sense of perspective.
[05:23:26,216,05:23:33,982] Daily habits are powerful because of how they compound, but worrying too much about every daily choice is like looking at yourself in the mirror from an inch away.
[05:23:34,763,05:23:39,467] You can see every imperfection and lose sight of the bigger picture. There is too much feedback.
[05:23:40,568,05:23:44,211] Conversely, never reviewing your habits is like never looking in the mirror.
[05:23:44,711,05:23:49,495] You aren't aware of easily fixable flaws, a spot on your shirt, a bit of food in your teeth.
[05:23:50,036,05:23:51,117] There is too little feedback.
[05:23:52,201,05:23:57,205] But periodic reflection and review is like viewing yourself in the mirror from a conversational distance.
[05:23:57,745,05:24:01,668] You can see the important changes you should make without losing sight of the bigger picture.
[05:24:02,309,05:24:06,112] You want to view the entire mountain range, not obsess over each peak and valley.
[05:24:07,213,05:24:14,198] Finally, reflection and review offers an ideal time to revisit one of the most important aspects of behavior change, identity.
[05:24:16,600,05:24:18,582] How to break the beliefs that hold you back.
[05:24:19,888,05:24:24,792] In the beginning, repeating a habit is essential to build up evidence of your desired identity.
[05:24:25,652,05:24:31,437] As you latch on to that new identity, however, those same beliefs can hold you back from the next level of growth.
[05:24:32,357,05:24:40,103] When working against you, your identity creates a kind of pride that encourages you to deny your weak spots and prevents you from truly growing.
[05:24:41,044,05:24:43,626] This is one of the greatest downsides of building habits.
[05:24:44,888,05:24:52,674] The more sacred an idea is to us, that is, the more deeply it is tied to our identity, the more strongly we will defend it against criticism.
[05:24:53,334,05:24:54,855] You see this in every industry.
[05:24:55,556,05:25:00,399] The school teacher who ignores innovative teaching methods and sticks with her tried and true lesson plans.
[05:25:01,340,05:25:04,302] The veteran manager who is committed to doing things his way.
[05:25:05,283,05:25:08,365] The surgeon who dismisses the ideas of her younger colleagues.
[05:25:09,105,05:25:12,788] The band who produces a mind-blowing first album and then gets stuck in a rut.
[05:25:14,031,05:25:17,855] The tighter we cling to an identity, the harder it becomes to grow beyond it.
[05:25:19,016,05:25:24,862] One solution is to avoid making any single aspect of your identity an overwhelming portion of who you are.
[05:25:25,643,05:25:28,906] In the words of investor Paul Graham, keep your identity small.
[05:25:29,767,05:25:35,232] The more you let a single belief define you, the less capable you are of adapting when life challenges you.
[05:25:36,130,05:25:44,054] If you tie up everything in being the point guard or the partner at the firm or whatever else, then the loss of that facet of your life will wreck you.
[05:25:44,974,05:25:51,417] If you're a vegan and then develop a health condition that forces you to change your diet, you'll have an identity crisis on your hands.
[05:25:52,257,05:25:58,020] When you cling too tightly to one identity, you become brittle. Lose that one thing and you lose yourself.
[05:25:59,445,05:26:03,346] For most of my young life, being an athlete was a major part of my identity.
[05:26:04,107,05:26:06,887] After my baseball career ended, I struggled to find myself.
[05:26:07,648,05:26:12,249] When you spend your whole life defining yourself in one way, and that disappears, who are you now?
[05:26:13,530,05:26:16,971] Military veterans and former entrepreneurs report similar feelings.
[05:26:17,731,05:26:23,273] If your identity is wrapped up in a belief like, I'm a great soldier, what happens after your period of service ends?
[05:26:24,403,05:26:30,335] For many business owners, their identity is something along the lines of, I'm the CEO, or I'm the founder.
[05:26:31,397,05:26:36,046] If you have spent every waking moment working on your business, how will you feel after you sell the company?
[05:26:37,242,05:26:46,804] The key to mitigating these losses of identity is to redefine yourself such that you get to keep important aspects of your identity even if your particular role changes.
[05:26:47,404,05:26:53,505] So, I am an athlete becomes, I'm the type of person who is mentally tough and loves a physical challenge.
[05:26:54,265,05:27:00,767] Or, I'm a great soldier transforms into, I'm the type of person who is disciplined, reliable, and great on a team.
[05:27:01,907,05:27:06,468] I'm the CEO translates to, I'm the type of person who builds and creates things.
[05:27:07,988,05:27:11,911] When chosen effectively, an identity can be flexible rather than brittle.
[05:27:12,772,05:27:18,817] Like water flowing around an obstacle, your identity works with the changing circumstances rather than against them.
[05:27:20,158,05:27:23,861] The following quote from the Tao Te Ching encapsulates these ideas perfectly.
[05:27:25,362,05:27:32,088] Men are born soft and supple. Dead, they are stiff and hard. Plants are born tender and pliant.
[05:27:32,868,05:27:34,590] Dead, they are brittle and dry.
[05:27:35,709,05:27:43,534] Thus, whoever is stiff and inflexible is a disciple of death, whoever is soft and yielding is a disciple of life.
[05:27:44,594,05:27:49,237] The hard and the stiff will be broken, the soft and the supple will prevail.

[05:27:50,438,05:28:01,064] Lao Tzu Habits deliver numerous benefits, but the downside is that they can lock us into our previous patterns of thinking and acting, even when the world is shifting around us.
[05:28:01,933,05:28:04,915] Everything is impermanent. Life is constantly changing.
[05:28:05,355,05:28:09,737] So you need to periodically check in to see if your old habits and beliefs are still serving you.
[05:28:10,557,05:28:15,400] A lack of self-awareness is poison. Reflection and review is the antidote.
[05:28:17,661,05:28:22,263] Chapter Summary. The upside of habits is that we can do things without thinking.
[05:28:22,943,05:28:30,207] The downside is that we stop paying attention to little errors. Habits plus deliberate practice equal mastery.
[05:28:31,326,05:28:36,428] Reflection and review is a process that allows you to remain conscious of your performance over time.
[05:28:37,569,05:28:41,631] The tighter we cling to an identity, the harder it becomes to grow beyond it.
[05:28:46,493,05:28:49,215] Conclusion. The secret to results that last.
[05:28:52,196,05:29:00,080] There is an ancient Greek parable known as the Sorites paradox, which talks about the effect one small action can have when repeated enough times.
[05:29:01,080,05:29:05,801] One formulation of the paradox goes as follows. Can one coin make a person rich?
[05:29:06,821,05:29:10,962] If you give a person a pile of 10 coins, you wouldn't claim that he or she is rich.
[05:29:11,682,05:29:15,323] But what if you add another, and another, and another?
[05:29:16,543,05:29:22,184] At some point, you will have to admit that no one can be rich unless one coin can make him or her so.
[05:29:23,684,05:29:28,405] We can say the same about atomic habits. Can one tiny change transform your life?
[05:29:29,390,05:29:35,092] It is unlikely that you would say so. But what if you made another, and another, and another?
[05:29:36,152,05:29:40,393] At some point, you will have to admit that your life was transformed by one small change.
[05:29:41,634,05:29:46,435] The holy grail of habit change is not a single 1% improvement, but a thousand of them.
[05:29:47,495,05:29:52,757] It's a bunch of atomic habits stacking up, each one a fundamental unit of the overall system.
[05:29:54,283,05:29:59,708] In the beginning, small improvements can often seem meaningless because they get washed away by the weight of the system.
[05:30:00,769,05:30:09,858] Just as one coin won't make you rich, one positive change, like meditating for one minute or reading one page each day, is unlikely to deliver a noticeable difference.
[05:30:10,879,05:30:17,025] Gradually, though, as you continue to layer small changes on top of one another, the scales of life start to move.
[05:30:17,945,05:30:23,713] Each improvement is like adding a grain of sand to the positive side of the scale, slowly tilting things in your favor.
[05:30:24,614,05:30:30,602] Eventually, if you stick with it, you hit a tipping point. Suddenly, it feels easier to stick with good habits.
[05:30:31,263,05:30:34,287] The weight of the system is working for you rather than against you.
[05:30:35,745,05:30:39,628] Over the course of this book, we've looked at dozens of stories about top performers.

[05:30:40,308,05:30:52,938] We've heard about Olympic gold medalists, award-winning artists, business leaders, life-saving physicians, and star comedians who have all used the science of small habits to master their craft and vault to the top of their fields.

[05:30:54,176,05:31:05,965] Each of the people, teams, and companies we have covered has faced different circumstances, but ultimately progressed in the same way, through a commitment to tiny, sustainable, unrelenting improvements.
[05:31:07,166,05:31:14,252] Success is not a goal to reach or a finish line to cross. It is a system to improve, an endless process to refine.
